Maybe this could be written up and summarized with more references? That makes for a great argument for people to pick minority clients out of selifsh interests.

author: raphael1234
content: I think if a 67% majority finalizes the 'incorrect' chain that chain actually becomes the correct chain at that point. And assuming a lot of money is behind that majority I would say that it then stays that way.

author: pietjepuk
content:
This discussion has been had to some extent before, but I would personally like to have more clear answers on this hypothetical from client teams.

Either way, 67% of validators finalizing a wrong chain doesn't mean 67% of users (and their economic activity) is on that chain. With many people using e.g. infura or other centralized endpoints, those might be on the minority chain.

author: ajsutton
content:
This is absolutely incorrect. No amount of validator attestations can make an invalid chain valid, that would require a governance decision and spec change.  You're never going to get a definitive answer of what a governance decision will be ahead of time because Ethereum is decentralised there's no one to make such an authoritative statement. But as <@!397389662085185547> pointed out, majority of validators doesn't mean majority of economic value and validators are the new miners - they're not the point of the chain and very replaceable, so it's always going to be economic value that matters.

A couple of questions I find help reason about this:
 * If stakers don't lose money for doing the wrong thing, what's the basis for security in PoS?
 * If we'd really just follow the majority client in the case of a chain split, why are we investing all this time and money building multiple clients?

author: raphael1234
content: I just find it hard to wrap my head around that. Would a majority of validators (might even be multiple clients failing) voting for the - technically - invalid chain not be that governance decision after all? It would be not intentional for sure.

author: ajsutton
content: No. Definitely not. Validators are not in charge of Ethereum governance. What you're suggesting is equivalent to saying that miners are in control of Ethereum today and could fork the chain however and whenever they wanted.

author: ajsutton
content: And if you aren't sure how much say miners have in Ethereum governance, take a look at the massive push they had against EIP 1559 and the result of that.

author: tokey1475
content: You are correct of course, but it seems like we are setting ourselves up for a disaster here, especially given that many exchanges are running the super majority client and will therefore have a lot of economic value backing them.  Do you have any thoughts on raising the supermajority cutoff above the current 2/3?  With one client representing a supermajority aren't we already sacrificing much of the benefit behind having mulitple clients?

author: ajsutton
content:
We should absolutely avoid having one client with a supermajority and advocacy is under way to get to get to a better spread. Not sure that increasing the finalization requirement is necessarily a good plan - if we have highly uneven client usage then we still have problems and ultimately we need to do something to get to a more even spread, not just keep shifting goal posts to avoid (potential) disaster.

It's very important to note that no exchange is running any CL client as part of their actual exchange operation (ie for following transactions) because the CL doesn't have anything to do with transactions until the merge. Clear communication of the risks of using a single client to verify off-chain transactions now is likely the right result so they design a setup that doesn't put them at risk.

author: tokey1475
content: Totally agree on the first point and hats off the the ethstaker crew and everyone else reaching out.  I hope they succeed.  Also agreed that moving the goal posts isn't a great solution.  But if times goes on and the diversity metrics don't improve and we have to choose between raising the finality cutoff,  delaying the merge, or going ahead with a supermajority client, moving the  goals posts may be the best option.
